Benchmark.title: CIS Mozilla Firefox 38 ESR Benchmark

description.p: This document provides prescriptive guidance for establishing a secure configuration posture for the Mozilla Firefox 38 ESR Browser. This guide was tested against Mozilla Firefox 38.2.0ESR. To obtain the latest version of this guide, please visit http://benchmarks.cisecurity.org. If you have questions, comments, or have identified ways to improve this guide, please write us at feedback@cisecurity.org.

description.p: This section describes how to enable locked preferences for Firefox. The files outlined in this section are used to configure most of the other recommendations listed in this benchmark.
The local-settings.js file is used by Firefox to reference and load the mozilla.cfg file which contains all the locked preferences.

rationale.p: Loading a custom configuration file is a primary mechanism for setting and enforcing security requirements within Firefox.

li.span: directory inside the Firefox installation directory and create a file called

description.p: Set permissions on local-settings.js so that it can only be modified or deleted by an Administrator.

rationale.p: Any users with the ability to modify the local-settings.js file can bypass all security configurations by changing the file or deleting it.

p.p: Deny non-administrators the ability to write to local-settings.js.

description.p: The mozilla.cfg file is used by Firefox to configure all the locked preferences.

rationale.p: Loading a custom configuration file is a primary mechanism for setting and enforcing security requirements in Firefox.

li.span: Firefox installation directory and create a file called
The first line of the file must be a comment:

description.p: Set permissions on mozilla.cfg so that it can only be modified or deleted by an Administrator.

rationale.p: Any users with the ability to modify the mozilla.cfg file can bypass all security configurations by changing the file or deleting it.

p.p: Deny non-administrators the ability to write to mozilla.cfg.

description.p: Ensure that Firefox is installed and owned by an administrative account in order to protect the binaries and to prevent users from circumventing security settings.

rationale.p: When Firefox is installed by an ordinary user, the software in installed into the user's profile / home directory. This avoids the requirement for administrative access during installation and upgrades, but also allows users to circumvent security settings defined in settings.js and mozilla.cfg files. Having the installation owned by an administrative user can also protect binary and configuration files from malware that is executed in an ordinary user's browser.

p.p: Install Firefox into a shared location that can be accessed by users but modified only by Administrators.
Ordinary users will not be able to update or patch Firefox; only Administrators can perform upgrades.

description.p: This section will discuss how to enable auto updates in Firefox.
This feature configures Firefox to automatically download and install updates as they are made available.

rationale.p: Security updates ensure that users are safe from known software bugs and vulnerabilities.

ol.li: Open the mozilla.cfg file in the installation directory with a text editor

description.p: This feature automatically detects when installed plugins are out of date and notifies the users to update the plugins.

rationale.p: Outdated plugins can be vulnerable or unstable, and can be exploited by malicious websites.

ol.li: Open the mozilla.cfg file in the installation directory with a text editor
Add the following lines to mozilla.cfg:lockPref("plugins.update.notifyUser", true);

Rule.title: (L1) Enable Information Bar for Outdated Plugins

description.p: This feature automatically shows an information bar when installed Plugins are out of date and notifies the users to update the plugins.

rationale.p: Outdated plugins can be vulnerable or unstable, and can be exploited by malicious websites.

ol.li: Open the mozilla.cfg file in the installation directory with a text editor
Add the following lines to mozilla.cfg:lockPref("plugins.hide_infobar_for_outdated_plugin", false);

description.p: This configuration sets the amount of time the system waits in between each check for updates.

rationale.p: Frequent checks for updates will mitigate the risk that a system is left vulnerable to known risks for an extended period of time.

ol.li: Open the mozilla.cfg file in the installation directory with a text editor
Add the following lines to mozilla.cfg:lockPref("app.update.interval", 43200);

p.p: app.update.enabled must be set to true for this preference to take effect.

description.p: This setting determines the amount of time, in seconds, which the system will wait before displaying the Software Update dialogue box (after an unobtrusive alert has already been shown).

rationale.p: Encouraging the user to update software as soon as possible mitigates the risk that a system will be left vulnerable.

ol.li: Open the mozilla.cfg file in the installation directory with a text editor
Add the following lines to mozilla.cfg:lockPref("app.update.promptWaitTime", 172800);
For this preference to have an effect app.update.enabled must be true and app.update.silent must be false.
The full Software Update dialog is still subject toapp.update.idletime.

Rule.title: (L1) Ensure Update-related UI Components are Displayed

description.p: This setting dictates whether the Firefox Update service will notify the user when update related events occur, such as updates being available or downloaded. It is recommended that updated-related notifications be displayed.

rationale.p: Ensuring users are aware of update-related events may reduce the amount of time Firefox remains unpatched.

ol.li: Open the mozilla.cfg file in the installation directory with a text editor
Add the following lines to mozilla.cfg:lockPref("app.update.silent", false);

description.p: This feature dictates whether Firefox will update installed search providers. Search providers allow the user to search directly from the "Search bar" which is adjacent to the URL bar.

rationale.p: Software updates help ensure that users are safe from known software bugs and vulnerabilities.

ol.li: Open the mozilla.cfg file in the installation directory with a text editor
Add the following lines to mozilla.cfg: lockPref("browser.search.update", true);

description.p: This section provides guidance for configuring portions of Firefox exposed via the Network Settings dialog.

Firefox can be configured to use one or more proxy servers. When a proxy server is configured for a given protocol (HTTP, FTP, Gopher, etc), Firefox will send applicable requests to that proxy server for fulfillment. It is recommended that the list of proxy servers configured in Firefox be reviewed to ensure it contains only trusted proxy servers.

rationale.p: Depending on the protocol used, the proxy server will have access to read and/or alter all information communicated between Firefox and the target server, such a web site.

ol.li: Drop down the Firefox menu
Click on Options
Select Options from the list
Click on the Advanced Button in the Options window
Click on Network Tab
Click on Settings Button
Ensure that the proxy listed (if any) is the one configured and approved by the enterprise.

Rule.title: (L2) Do Not Send Cross SSL/TLS Referrer Header

description.p: This preference dictates whether Firefox will send the URL of the SSL/TLS-protected referring site to the referred SSL/TLS protected site.

rationale.p: The URL of the SSL-protected referring site may contain sensitive information. Preventing this URL from being sent mitigates the risk that the sensitive information will be disclosed.

ol.li: Open the mozilla.cfg file in the installation directory with a text editor
Add the following lines to mozilla.cfg:lockPref("network.http.sendSecureXSiteReferrer", false);

p.p: Enabling this setting may negatively impact the functionality of websites that rely on receiving referrer information.

description.p: This feature NT Lan Manager (NTLM) v1 protocol to be used for authentication to resources that request this authentication type.

rationale.p: NTLM v1 contains cryptographic weaknesses that can be easily exploited to obtain user credentials.

ol.li: Open the mozilla.cfg file in the installation directory with a text editor
Add the following lines to mozilla.cfg:lockPref("network.auth.force-generic-ntlm-v1", false);

p.p: This may effect websites and browsers that require the use of NTLM v1

description.p: It is possible to disguise a website's true location by making use of username/password syntax within the URL (known as "phishy URLs"). This setting will display a warning message whenever a user clicks a link to a phishy URL.

p.span: This setting will help protect the browser against phishing.

ol.li: Open the mozilla.cfg file in the installation directory with a text editor
Add the following lines to mozilla.cfg:lockPref("network.http.phishy-userpass-length", 1);

description.p: This feature determines whether all Internationalized Domain Names (IDNs) displayed in the browser are displayed as Punycode or as Unicode.

rationale.p: IDNs displayed in Punycode are easier to identify and therefore help mitigate the risk of accessing spoofed web pages.

ol.li: Open the mozilla.cfg file in the installation directory with a text editor
Add the following lines to mozilla.cfg:lockPref("network.IDN_show_punycode", true);

description.p: This feature determines the restrictions placed on the scripts and links loaded into the browser from local HTML files.

rationale.p: Applying the same origin policy to local files will help mitigate the risk of unauthorized access to sensitive information.

ol.li: Open the mozilla.cfg file in the installation directory with a text editor
Add the following lines to mozilla.cfg:lockPref("security.fileuri.strict_origin_policy", true)

description.p: Firefox allows users to sync preferences and settings, including saved credentials, to cloud-based servers in order to retrieve them from other computers. This setting determines whether cloud sync in enabled.

rationale.p: Disable cloud sync in order to ensure that personal data and credentials are not compromised.

ol.li: Open the mozilla.cfg file in the installation directory with a text editor
Add the following lines to mozilla.cfg:lockPref("services.sync.enabled", false);

description.p: These settings determine whether WebRTC (Web Real Time Communications) is allowed. WebRTC is used for peer to peer communication such as file sharing or video calls.

rationale.p: WebRTC can expose private information such as internal IP addresses and computer settings.

ol.li: Open the mozilla.cfg file in the installation directory with a text editor

description.p: This section will discuss how to set up encryption settings in Firefox.

When Firefox encounters an invalid certificate and the user clicks "Add Exception", a dialog is displayed with a text box to fetch the certificate from the given URL. This preference controls whether Firefox will or will not automatically fill in the URL text box and auto-fetch the certificate on behalf of the user. Setting this preference to 0 forces the user to enter a URL and click the "Get Certificate" button before adding an exception for an invalid cert.

rationale.p: Requiring the user to manually enter the server's URL and fetch the certificate may provide additional opportunity to scrutinize the certificate before adding an exception for a potentially fraudulent certificate.

ol.li: Open the mozilla.cfg file in the installation directory with a text editor
Add the following lines to mozilla.cfg:lockPref("browser.ssl_override_behavior", 0);

span.span: sets the maximum required protocol version.

p.span: Setting TLS 1.2 as the maximum authorized protocol version mitigates the risk of using an insecure connection.

ol.li: Open the mozilla.cfg file in the installation directory with a text editor
Add the following lines to mozilla.cfg:lockPref("security.tls.version.max", 3)

description.p: This feature sets the minimum protocol version that may be used when negotiating TLS/SSL sessions.

rationale.p: Setting TLS 1.0 as the minimum protocol version mitigates the risk of negotiating an insecure protocol, such as SSL 2.0.

ol.li: Open the mozilla.cfg file in the installation directory with a text editor
Add the following lines to mozilla.cfg:lockPref("security.tls.version.min", 1)

p.span: This setting dictates whether Firefox will leverage Online Certificate Status Protocol (OCSP) to determine if a given certificate has been revoked.
Leveraging OCSP may help identify revoked certificates.

ol.li: Open the mozilla.cfg file in the installation directory with a text editor
Add the following lines to mozilla.cfg:lockPref("security.OCSP.enabled", 1)

p.p: Enabling OCSP carries potential privacy implications. For each HTTPS site Firefox visits, a request is sent to an OCSP server to determine if the site's certificate has been revoked. This provides the OCSP server with the IP address of the requester (Firefox or NAT) and, among other properties, the domain name of the site Firefox is accessing.
Firefox 26 and greater support OCSP Stapling, which mitigates the aforementioned privacy implications of using OCSP.

description.p: This feature disables the ability to view HTTP content such as JavaScript, CSS, objects, and xhr requests.

rationale.p: Blocking active mixed content minimizes the risk of man-in-the-middle attacks.

ol.li: Open the mozilla.cfg file in the installation directory with a text editor
Add the following lines to mozilla.cfg:lockPref("security.mixed_content.block_active_content", true)

description.p: This setting dictates whether Firefox will consider a given certificate to be invalid if Firefox is unable to obtain an Online Certificate Status Protocol (OCSP) response for it.

rationale.p: Requiring an OCSP response will reduce an adversary's ability to successfully leverage a compromised and revoked certificate.

ol.li: Open the mozilla.cfg file in the installation directory with a text editor
Add the following lines to mozilla.cfg:lockPref("security.ocsp.require", true);

p.p: Enabling OCSP carries potential privacy implications. For each HTTPS site Firefox visits, a request is sent to an OCSP server to determine if the site's certificate has been revoked. This provides the OCSP server with the IP address of the requester (Firefox or NAT) and, among other properties, the domain name of the site Firefox is accessing.
Additionally, requiring an OCSP response increases opportunity for valid certificates to be deemed invalid. This may occur if OCSP server becomes unavailable or is not accessible.
Firefox 26+ support OCSP Stapling which mitigates the aforementioned privacy implications.

description.p: This section will provide guidance on how to use advanced JavaScript settings to guard against certain attacks.

Rule.title: (L1) Disallow JavaScript's Ability to Change the Status Bar Text

description.p: The Status Bar shows the location of the content when a user hovers over a hyperlink, a user visits a link, or when content is being downloaded on a web page.

rationale.p: Some malicious websites can use JavaScript to manipulate the text on the status bar so that a user cannot determine the actual location of the content for hyperlinks and downloads.

ol.li: Open the mozilla.cfg file in the installation directory with a text editor
Add the following lines to mozilla.cfg:lockPref("dom.disable_window_status_change", true);

Rule.title: (L1) Disable Scripting of Plugins by JavaScript

description.p: Javascript can initiate and interact with the Plug-ins installed in Firefox.

rationale.p: This may reduce a malicious script's ability to exploit vulnerabilities in plug-ins or abuse plug-in features.

ol.li: Open the mozilla.cfg file in the installation directory with a text editor
Add the following lines to mozilla.cfg:lockPref("security.xpconnect.plugin.unrestricted", false);

Rule.title: (L1) Disallow JavaScript's Ability to Hide the Address Bar

p.span: The Address Bar shows the current URL, which can be used to identify the website.
Some malicious websites can use JavaScript to hide the address bar so that a user cannot determine the URL.

ol.li: Open the mozilla.cfg file in the installation directory with a text editor
Add the following lines to mozilla.cfg:lockPref("dom.disable_window_open_feature.location", true);

Rule.title: (L1) Disallow JavaScript's Ability to Hide the Status Bar

description.p: The Status Bar shows the location of the content when a user visits a link or when content is being downloaded on a web page.

rationale.p: Some malicious websites can use JavaScript to hide the status bar so that a user cannot determine the location of the content for hyperlinks and downloads.

ol.li: Open the mozilla.cfg file in the installation directory with a text editor
Add the following lines to mozilla.cfg:lockPref("dom.disable_window_open_feature.status", true);

Rule.title: (L1) Disable Closing of Windows via Scripts

description.p: Firefox can be configured to prevent scripts from closing browser windows.

rationale.p: Preventing an arbitrary web site from closing the browser window will reduce the probability of a user losing work or state being performed in another tab within the same window.

ol.li: Open the mozilla.cfg file in the installation directory with a text editor
Add the following lines to mozilla.cfg:lockPref("dom.allow_scripts_to_close_windows", false);

description.p: The Pop-up Blocker is used to block Pop-ups which a website might open with or without any user interaction. These Pop-Ups can be used to open un-trusted malicious content.

rationale.p: By enabling the Pop-up blocker, all Pop-ups will be blocked which will guard a user against any attacks launched using a Pop-up.

ol.li: Open the mozilla.cfg file in the installation directory with a text editor
Add the following lines to mozilla.cfg:lockPref("privacy.popups.policy", 1);

Rule.title: (L1) Disable Displaying JavaScript in History URLs

description.p: This will ensure that JavaScript URLs are not displayed in the history bar.

rationale.p: Various browser elements, even a simple link, can embed javascript: URLs and access the javascript: protocol. The JavaScript statement used in a javascript: URL can be used to encapsulate a specially crafted URL that performs a malicious function.

ol.li: Open the mozilla.cfg file in the installation directory with a text editor
Add the following lines to mozilla.cfg:lockPref("browser.urlbar.filter.javascript", true);

description.p: This sections contains recommendations pertaining largely to privacy as it relates to browsing behaviors. While Firefox contains several settings that allow a user to sanitize and/or avoid persisting browsing artifacts, such as download history, caches, form data, etc, this section does not contain recommendations for configuring such settings. Users concerned with the privacy implications of such artifacts are encouraged to browse in a "Private Window". For more information on private browsing in Firefox, please see: https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/private-browsing-browse-web-without-saving-info.
Firefox allows credentials to be stored for certain websites.

rationale.p: Stored credentials may be harvested by an adversary that gains local privileges equal to or greater than the principal running Firefox, which may increase the scope and impact of a breach. However, preventing Firefox from storing credentials will not prevent such an adversary from harvesting credentials used while compromised.

ol.li: Open the mozilla.cfg file in the installation directory with a text editor
Add the following lines to mozilla.cfg:lockPref("signon.rememberSignons", false);

Rule.title: (L1) Do Not Accept Third Party Cookies

description.p: A third-party cookie is a cookie sent by a domain that differs from the domain in the browser's address bar.

rationale.p: Third party cookies are often used for tracking user browsing behaviors, which has privacy implications. However, preventing third-party cookies does not completely mitigate privacy concerns as several other active tracking mechanisms exist[1].

ol.li: Open the mozilla.cfg file in the installation directory with a text editor
Add the following lines to mozilla.cfg:lockPref("network.cookie.cookieBehavior", 1);

p.p: Blocking third-party cookies may adversely effect the functionality of some sites.

description.p: These settings instruct the browser to communicate the preference not to be tracked to websites to which it connects, and additionally attempt to block tracking.

rationale.p: Enabling Do Not Track instructs the browser to send an optional header in HTTP requests made from the app that indicates a preference not to be tracked by websites. This optional header is voluntary in nature, having no method to enforce adherence and providing no guarantee that web sites will honor the preference. However, a large number of websites do honor it so there is privacy benefit in enabling it.

ol.li: Open the mozilla.cfg file in the installation directory with a text editor

Rule.title: (L1) Set Delay for Enabling Security Sensitive Dialog Boxes

p.span: This feature sets the amount of time in milliseconds that elapse before the buttons on security-sensitive dialog boxes are enabled.

rationale.p: This delay help prevents Firefox users from inadvertently installing malicious software.

ol.li: Open the mozilla.cfg file in the installation directory with a text editor
Add the following lines to mozilla.cfg:lockPref("security.dialog_enable_delay", 2000);

description.p: This settings determines whether Firefox will provide geographic location information to websites.

rationale.p: Geo-location services can expose private information to remote websites.

ol.li: Open the mozilla.cfg file in the installation directory with a text editor
Add the following lines to mozilla.cfg:lockPref("geo.enabled", false);

description.p: This sections contains recommendations related to how Firefox manages extensions and add-ons.
Some active content such as audio and video can be automatically loaded by Firefox on websites. It is recommended to secure application plug-ins.

rationale.p: Some malicious websites use active content to exploit vulnerabilities in the active content handling application plug-in. It is recommended to always prompt the user when a website is about to load active content.

ol.li: Open the mozilla.cfg file in the installation directory with a text editor
Add the following lines to mozilla.cfg:lockPref("browser.helperApps.alwaysAsk.force", true);

description.p: This configuration will show how to ensure that no website is allowed to automatically install Add-Ons. Also, it will list how to ensure that proper notifications are shown when installing Add-Ons.

rationale.p: Add-Ons are extensions of the browser that add new functionality to Firefox or change its appearance. These run in a user s session allowing them do manipulate data and the behavior of the way Firefox interacts with other application and user commands. If malicious Add-Ons are installed automatically, a user s security could be completely compromised.

ol.li: Open the mozilla.cfg file in the installation directory with a text editor
Add the following lines to mozilla.cfg:lockPref("xpinstall.whitelist.required", true);

description.p: This feature enables Mozilla to retrieve a list of blocked applications from the server.

rationale.p: Enabling Mozilla to access the list of blocked applications mitigates the risk of installing a known malicious application.

ol.li: Open the mozilla.cfg file in the installation directory with a text editor
Add the following lines to mozilla.cfg:lockPref("extensions.blocklist.enabled", true);

p.span: This feature determines how often Mozilla will attempt to retrieve a list of blocked applications from the server.
An updated list of blocked applications mitigates the risk of installing and using a known malicious application.

ol.li: Open the mozilla.cfg file in the installation directory with a text editor
Add the following lines to mozilla.cfg:lockPref("extensions.blocklist.interval", 86400);

Rule.title: (L1) Enable Warning for External Protocol Handler

p.span: This feature indicates whether the user is warned before opening an external application for pre-configured protocols were its behavior is undefined.

rationale.p: Enabling a warning to appear before passing data to an external application mitigates the risk that sensitive information will be made vulnerable to outside threats.

ol.li: Open the mozilla.cfg file in the installation directory with a text editor
Add the following lines to mozilla.cfg:lockPref("network.protocol-handler.warn-external-default", true);

description.p: This feature controls popups that are initiated by plugins.

rationale.p: Disabling plugin popups (except from white-listed sites) from being displayed, guard a user against any attacks launched using a Pop-up.

ol.li: Open the mozilla.cfg file in the installation directory with a text editor
Add the following lines to mozilla.cfg:lockPref("privacy.popups.disable_from_plugins", 2)

p.span: This feature configures Firefox to automatically download and install updates as they are made available.
Security updates ensure that users are safe from known software bugs and vulnerabilities.

ol.li: Open the mozilla.cfg file in the installation directory with a text editor
Add the following lines to mozilla.cfg:lockPref("extensions.update.autoUpdateDefault", true)

p.span: This feature configures Firefox to prompt when updates are made available.
Security updates ensure that users are safe from known software bugs and vulnerabilities.

ol.li: Open the mozilla.cfg file in the installation directory with a text editor
Add the following lines to mozilla.cfg:lockPref("extensions.update.enabled", true)

Rule.title: (L1) Set Extension Update Interval Time Checks

p.span: This feature sets the amount of time the system waits between checking for updates.
Setting a specific amount of time between automatically checking for updates mitigates the risk that a system will left vulnerable to known risks for an extended period of time.

ol.li: Open the mozilla.cfg file in the installation directory with a text editor
Add the following lines to mozilla.cfg:lockPref("extensions.update.interval", 86400)

description.p: This sections contains recommendations for configuring FireFox's malware-related settings.
This feature configures the browser to scan downloads for viruses.

rationale.p: This will ensure that a downloaded file is scanned for viruses before the user has an opportunity to interact with the download. It will also ensure that Windows Policy for downloaded files is followed properly.

ol.li: Open the mozilla.cfg file in the installation directory with a text editor
Add the following lines to mozilla.cfg:lockPref("browser.download.manager.scanWhenDone", true);

Rule.title: (L1) Disable JAR from Opening Unsafe File Types

description.p: This feature gives the user the ability to override the restriction on only loading files with application/java-archive or application/x-jar content types.

rationale.p: Enabling the browser to only load application/java-archive or application/x-jar content types mitigates the risk of malware infection and other attack vectors.

ol.li: Open the mozilla.cfg file in the installation directory with a text editor
Add the following lines to mozilla.cfg: lockPref("network.jar.open-unsafe-types", false);

p.span: This feature alerts the user if they are visiting a known phishing website.

rationale.p: Enabling this feature helps mitigate the threat of phishing attacks.

ol.li: Open the mozilla.cfg file in the installation directory with a text editor
Add the following lines to mozilla.cfg:lockPref("browser.safebrowsing.enabled", true);

description.p: This feature alerts the user if they are visiting a known malicious website.

rationale.p: Enabling this feature will decrease the probability of a user falling victim to a known malicious web site.

ol.li: Open the mozilla.cfg file in the installation directory with a text editor
Add the following lines to mozilla.cfg:lockPref("browser.safebrowsing.malware.enabled", true);
